questions.question: Find which of the variables $x, y, z$ and $u$ represent rational or irrational numbers:
questions.solution:
• (i) $x^2 = 5 \Rightarrow x = \sqrt{5}$. Since 5 is not a perfect square, $x$ is an irrational number.
  • (ii) $y^2 = 9 \Rightarrow y = \sqrt{9} = 3$. Since 3 is an integer, $y$ is a rational number.
  • (iii) $z^2 = 0.04 \Rightarrow z = \sqrt{0.04} = 0.2$. Since 0.2 is a terminating decimal, $z$ is a rational number.
  • (iv) $u^2 = \frac{17}{4} \Rightarrow u = \sqrt{\frac{17}{4}} = \frac{\sqrt{17}}{2}$. Since 17 is not a perfect square, $u$ is an irrational number.

questions.question: Find three rational numbers between:
questions.solution:
(i) -1 and -2

$-1.1, -1.2, -1.3$

(ii) 0.1 and 0.11

$0.101, 0.102, 0.103$

(iii) $\frac{5}{7}$ and $\frac{6}{7}$

$\frac{50}{70}, \frac{60}{70} \Rightarrow \frac{51}{70}, \frac{52}{70}, \frac{53}{70}$

(iv) $\frac{1}{4}$ and $\frac{1}{5}$

$\frac{1}{4}=0.25, \frac{1}{5}=0.20 \Rightarrow 0.21, 0.22, 0.23$

questions.question: Insert a rational number and an irrational number between the following:
questions.solution:
(i) Between 2 and 3

Rational: $2.5$ (or $\frac{5}{2}$)
Irrational: $\sqrt{5} \approx 2.236...$

(ii) Between 0 and 0.1

Rational: $0.05$
Irrational: $0.010010001...$ (Non-terminating, non-recurring)

(iii) Between $\frac{1}{3} (0.33...)$ and $\frac{1}{2} (0.5)$

Rational: $0.4$
Irrational: $0.414114111...$

(iv) $\frac{-2}{5}$ and $\frac{1}{2}$

Rational: $0$
Irrational: $0.101001...$

(v) 0.15 and 0.16

Rational: $0.151$
Irrational: $0.15101001...$

(vi) $\sqrt{2} (1.414...)$ and $\sqrt{3} (1.732...)$

Rational: $1.5$
Irrational: $1.505005...$

(vii) 2.357 and 3.121

Rational: $3$
Irrational: $3.01001...$

(viii) .0001 and .001

Rational: $0.0002$
Irrational: $0.0001101...$

(ix) 3.623623... and 0.484848...

Rational: $1$
Irrational: $1.101001...$

(x) 6.375289... and 6.375738...

Rational: $6.3753$
Irrational: $6.375301001...$

questions.question: Represent the following numbers on the number line:
questions.solution:
(i) 7: Mark point 7 on the positive side of the number line.

(ii) 7.2: Mark the 2nd small division after 7 (if 1 unit = 10 divisions).

(iii) -3/2: This is -1.5. Mark the point exactly halfway between -1 and -2.

(iv) -12/5: This is -2.4. Mark the 4th small division after -2 towards -3.

questions.question: Locate $\sqrt{5}, \sqrt{10}$ and $\sqrt{17}$ on the number line.
questions.solution:
$\sqrt{5}$: Construct a right triangle with base 2 and height 1. Hypotenuse = $\sqrt{2^2+1^2} = \sqrt{5}$. Draw an arc from 0 with this radius to cut the number line.

$\sqrt{10}$: Construct a right triangle with base 3 and height 1. Hypotenuse = $\sqrt{3^2+1^2} = \sqrt{10}$.

$\sqrt{17}$: Construct a right triangle with base 4 and height 1. Hypotenuse = $\sqrt{4^2+1^2} = \sqrt{17}$.

questions.question: Represent geometrically the following numbers on the number line:
questions.solution:
Method: To represent $\sqrt{x}$:

  1. Draw a line segment $AB = x$ units.
  2. Extend $AB$ to $C$ such that $BC = 1$ unit.
  3. Find the mid-point $O$ of $AC$.
  4. Draw a semi-circle with centre $O$ and radius $OA$.
  5. Draw a perpendicular at $B$ intersecting the semi-circle at $D$.
  6. The length $BD = \sqrt{x}$.
  7. With $B$ as centre and radius $BD$, draw an arc cutting the number line. This point represents $\sqrt{x}$.
  8. Repeat for all values (4.5, 5.6, 8.1, 2.3).

questions.question: Express the following in the form $\frac{p}{q}$, where $p, q$ are integers and $q \neq 0$:
questions.solution:
(i) $0.2 = \frac{2}{10} = \frac{1}{5}$

(ii) Let $x = 0.888... \Rightarrow 10x = 8.888... \Rightarrow 9x = 8 \Rightarrow x = \frac{8}{9}$

(iii) Let $x = 5.222... \Rightarrow 10x = 52.222... \Rightarrow 9x = 47 \Rightarrow x = \frac{47}{9}$

(iv) Let $x = 0.001001... \Rightarrow 1000x = 1.001001... \Rightarrow 999x = 1 \Rightarrow x = \frac{1}{999}$

(v) $0.2555... = \frac{23}{90}$

(vi) $0.1\overline{34} = \frac{133}{990}$

(vii) $0.003232... = \frac{32}{9900} = \frac{8}{2475}$

(viii) $0.4040... = \frac{40}{99}$

questions.question: Simplify the following:
questions.solution:
(i)

$= 3(3\sqrt{5}) - 5\sqrt{5} + 10\sqrt{2} - 5\sqrt{2}$

$= 9\sqrt{5} - 5\sqrt{5} + 5\sqrt{2} = 4\sqrt{5} + 5\sqrt{2}$

(ii)

$= 2\sqrt{5} - 3\sqrt{5} + \sqrt{\frac{5}{9}} = -\sqrt{5} + \frac{\sqrt{5}}{3} = -\frac{2\sqrt{5}}{3}$

(iii)

$= 6\sqrt{2} + 20\sqrt{2} - 3\sqrt{2} = 23\sqrt{2}$

(iv)

$= 10\sqrt{2} + 8\sqrt{2} - 2\sqrt{2} = 16\sqrt{2}$

(v)

$= 4\sqrt{3} + 15\sqrt{3} - 15\sqrt{3} = 4\sqrt{3}$

(vi)

$= 12\sqrt{3} - \frac{5}{6}\sqrt{3} + 4\sqrt{3} = \frac{91\sqrt{3}}{6}$

(vii)

$= 4\sqrt{3} + 12\sqrt{3} - \frac{5}{3}\sqrt{3} = \frac{43\sqrt{3}}{3}$

(viii)

$= 8\sqrt{3} - 5\sqrt{3} - 28\sqrt{3} = -25\sqrt{3}$

(ix)

$= 8\sqrt{3} - 5\sqrt{3} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} = \frac{8\sqrt{3}}{3}$

questions.question: Rationalise the denominator of the following:
questions.solution:
(i)

$\frac{2}{3\sqrt{3}} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{2\sqrt{3}}{3(3)} = \frac{2\sqrt{3}}{9}$

(ii) $\frac{16}{\sqrt{41}-5}$

$\frac{16(\sqrt{41}+5)}{41-25} = \frac{16(\sqrt{41}+5)}{16} = \sqrt{41}+5$

(iii)

$\frac{(2+\sqrt{3})^2}{4-3} = 7+4\sqrt{3}$

(iv)

$\frac{\sqrt{6}(\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2})}{3-2} = \sqrt{18}-\sqrt{12} = 3\sqrt{2}-2\sqrt{3}$

(v)

$\frac{(\sqrt{3}+1)(2\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})}{8-3} = \frac{2\sqrt{6}+3+2\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3}}{5}$

(vi)

$\frac{(\sqrt{5}+\sqrt{2})^2}{5-2} = \frac{7+2\sqrt{10}}{3}$

(vii)

$\frac{(\sqrt{3}-1)^2}{3-1} = \frac{4-2\sqrt{3}}{2} = 2-\sqrt{3}$

(viii)

$\frac{(3\sqrt{5}+\sqrt{3})(\sqrt{5}+\sqrt{3})}{5-3} = \frac{15+3\sqrt{15}+\sqrt{15}+3}{2} = 9+2\sqrt{15}$

(ix)

$\frac{4\sqrt{3}+5\sqrt{2}}{4\sqrt{3}+3\sqrt{2}} \times \frac{4\sqrt{3}-3\sqrt{2}}{4\sqrt{3}-3\sqrt{2}} = \frac{18+8\sqrt{6}}{30} = \frac{9+4\sqrt{6}}{15}$

questions.question: Find the values of $a$ and $b$ in each of the following:
questions.solution:
(i)

LHS $= \frac{(5+2\sqrt{3})(7-4\sqrt{3})}{49-48} = 35 - 20\sqrt{3} + 14\sqrt{3} - 24 = 11 - 6\sqrt{3}$.

$a = 11, b = -6$.

(ii)

LHS $= \frac{(3-\sqrt{5})(3-2\sqrt{5})}{9-20} = \frac{9-6\sqrt{5}-3\sqrt{5}+10}{-11} = \frac{19-9\sqrt{5}}{-11} = \frac{9}{11}\sqrt{5} - \frac{19}{11}$.

$a = \frac{9}{11}, b = \frac{19}{11}$.

(iii)

LHS $= \frac{(\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})(3\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3})}{18-12} = \frac{6+2\sqrt{6}+3\sqrt{6}+6}{6} = 2 + \frac{5}{6}\sqrt{6}$.

$b = -\frac{5}{6}$.

(iv)

LHS $= \frac{(7+\sqrt{5})^2 - (7-\sqrt{5})^2}{49-5} = \frac{28\sqrt{5}}{44} = \frac{7}{11}\sqrt{5}$.

$a = 0, b = 1$.

(v)

LHS $= 3\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{3}$. Compare with $3\sqrt{2} - a\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow a = -2$.

questions.question: Solve the following:
questions.solution:
(i)

$b = 5-2\sqrt{6} \Rightarrow a+b = 10, ab = 1 \Rightarrow a^2+b^2 = 98$

(ii)

$1/x = 3-\sqrt{8} \Rightarrow x+1/x = 6 \Rightarrow x^2+1/x^2 = 6^2-2 = 34$.

(iii)

$x=2+\sqrt{3}, y=2-\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow x+y=4, xy=1 \Rightarrow x^2+y^2+xy = 4^2-1 = 15$.

(iv)

$x=2+\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow (x-2)^2=3 \Rightarrow x^2-4x+1=0$. Divide polynomial to get remainder 3.

(v)

$1/x = 2-\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow x+1/x = 4 \Rightarrow x^2+1/x^2 = 14$.

questions.question: Evaluate the following:
questions.solution:
(i)

Simplify denominator: $3\sqrt{10} - 3\sqrt{5} \Rightarrow \frac{5}{\sqrt{10}-\sqrt{5}} = \sqrt{10}+\sqrt{5} = 5.398$

(ii)

Rationalise: $\frac{3\sqrt{2}+2\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{30}}{12}$.

(iii) - (vii)

Similar rationalisation process involving grouping terms and multiplying by conjugates twice.
